title.narrative: COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)
COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att lyfta några av Bangladeshs fattigaste kvinnor, som lever på landsbygden i delar av landet som är särskilt utsatta för klimatförändringarnas negativa effekter, ut ur extrem fattigdom genom att dra nytta av produktiva inkomstmöjligheter. Den primära målgruppen är 3600 kvinnor i Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha och Jamalpur distrikten även om betydligt fler människor, inklusive dessa kvinnors barn, kommer att dra viss nytta av projektets positiva effekter.
SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The overall objective of SWAPNO-II is to lift some of the poorest women, living in areas most vulnerable to natural hazards, out of poverty and help them sustain higher income levels after the project period. More specifically, the project aims to: - Increase the income and assets the target women have, - Enhance the human capabilities of these women for exercising choices, - Strengthen their resilience to shocks, including those created by natural disasters and climate change, - Enhance the financial inclusion to provide these women with more equitable opportunities, and - Improve policies and mechanisms for sustaining the benefits of this project and broaden its reach. SWAPNO-II will make different contributions to the women included in the different phases. For those who have already been employed in SWAPNO-I, this new phase will contribute with some additional learning, a few activities and follow-up to ensure that the benefits are sustainable. However, for the 3600 new beneficiaries, SWAPNO-II is intended to provide all of the above-mentioned results.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

title.narrative: Sustainable Graduation from Exxtreme Poverty of SWAPNO Women Project-II

description.narrative:
Year 2021 was one of the most significant periods for Strengthening Women's Ability for Productive New Opportunities- SWAPNO II project, given that the project reached up to the mid-way of its current project cycle and strongly advanced towards the expected outcome of the project. This Conclusion of Performance (CoP) covers the intended results achieved during the reporting period from September 2020 to August 2021 following the result chain, against the Result Resource Framework (RRF) of the contribution proposal.
This CoP has been prepared based on the annual progress report (for the period of 01 September 2020 to 31 August 2021) submitted in February 2022, different study reports conducted during the reporting period and two follow-up visits to the project sites steered during March and November 2021.
SWAPNO (Strengthening Women's Ability for Productive New Opportunities) is a poverty-reduction program based on rural and local multi-stakeholder partnerships as to strengthen public works and social transfers targeting ultra-poor rural women between 18 to 50 years of age who are widowed, divorced, abandoned, or left with a disabled husband. SWAPNO is implemented by the Local Government Division (LGD) and UNDP under the auspices of National Social Security Strategy (NSSS) of the Government of Bangladesh. The overall objective is Economic growth achieved in a more inclusive manner, with economic opportunities reaching rural poor women, and vulnerable groups are protected against shocks. The project is working towards five specific outcomes and each outcome has specific outputs and intended results. Below are the highlights and conclusions based on the progress of planned activities and outcome-wise results achieved so far:
Outcome 1 (Increased income and assets by expanding choices) focuses on SWAPNOs public works-based poverty graduation approach. The emphasis is on future employability. Women are intended to attain productive employment as to move themselves out of poverty through public works with training on market-based skills and productive employment. Contributing to this outcome, significant results have been achieved through the projects interventions. Firstly, the average monthly income and expenditure of the beneficiary households increased over time; the projects result assessment data 2021 (November December) revealed that the average monthly income of the beneficiary household (except wage-earning) is BDT 6,266 (USD 73.72), which is more than double compared to the baseline conducted 2019. But the monthly income of non-beneficiary households did not see any significant changes compared to the baseline. Its noted under the independent evaluation data from 2021 that the current productive assets of beneficiary households are BDT 160,299 (USD 1,908) which is 58% higher than that of the control group - BDT 101,907 (USD 1,213). The evaluation report also stated that the beneficiary households have 59% additional income through the additional income-generating activities facilitated by the project and more than 91% of women beneficiaries have their own choice to expand their assets and new income-generating activities which are 16% higher than the control group.
Outcome 2 (Enhanced human capabilities for exercising choices) focuses on enhancing conditions that promote women empowerment. Since inception, SWAPNO has been working to improve well-being and remove existing social and economic barriers of women in targeted districts so that they gradually can act on their decisions for graduating out of poverty. To achieve this, the project has been working in close collaboration with the Government, Local Government Institutions, and Implementing Partners (IPs). Under this outcome, the project has been focusing on a) developing knowledge and confidence levels through life skills training among beneficiaries, b) improving nutritional status by running a campaign and providing necessary inputs, and c) ensuring access to local justice systems to tackle Violence Against Women (VAW).
Its worth noting that evaluation (2021), revealed that the pro-active participation of the beneficiary households for securing the complementary services from the GoB is greater than that of the control households which must be considered a success. Further, around 95% of women beneficiaries have received local government services (IT relevant services i.e. computer, e-payment, bKash, Rocket, etc.) which is 55% for the control group of women; and around 62% of beneficiary women got health care services from the Union and the Upazila health clinic/hospital which is around 44% for control group women. In addition, the evaluation stated that the average dietary diversity score of the current beneficiary is higher than the baseline (the household dietary diversity average score of beneficiary households is 8 which was 6 in 2019).
Outcome 3 (Strengthened resilience to shocks including disasters and climate change) focuses on building the resilience of the women and their communities against systemic shocks including disasters and climate change. Specifically, this refers to the establishment and strengthening of coordination mechanisms, disaster risk reduction action plans, and to protect key public assets. The work under this Outcome has synergistically aligned with another Sweden funded project called LoGIC. Under this outcome, the project promoted climate smart technologies and provided training on Gender responsive Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change Adaptation to 4,093 Union Disaster Management Committee (UDMC) members (around 26% are female) through 43 master trainers 136 Union Parishads.
Under Outcome 3 the project also introduced climate-resilient agriculture approaches among the beneficiaries in the year 2020 and since then, they are producing different crops and vegetables within their homestead areas. The produce is mainly for self-consumption and the surplus is sold on the local market. To increase the use of organic fertilizers, SWAPNO trained 100 beneficiaries on vermicompost fertilizer production, and in the reporting period, the beneficiaries produced 30.8 metric tons of vermicompost whose present market value is BDT 461927.7 (USD 5,435). The beneficiaries have used the vermicompost fertilizer for vegetable cultivation and sold it to neighbors.
In addition to the above activities under Outcome 1-3, the project promoted tailoring and mask production, promoted a group farming approach through leasing land and need based small enterprises. To promote the widespread savings attitude and enhance group bonding among the projects beneficiaries, SWAPNO introduced the Fistful rice collection method in Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha, and Kurigram districts. As implied by the name, through this method, each beneficiary saves a handful of rice in a pot before cooking. After a fortnight, group members weigh their rice and sell those in the market. In this reporting year, 35,901 kg (35.9 metric ton) fistful rice is collected representing a market value of around BDT 1,436,040.00 (USD 16,894.59). This method has proven to be successful, and most of the beneficiaries invested the money in their income-generating activities after selling the fistful of rice.
Outcome 4 (Enhanced financial inclusion for equitable opportunities) focuses on promoting financial inclusion and strengthening the G2P (Government-to-person) digital payment system. The project ensured access to financial institutions for 100% of its beneficiaries. In this endeavor, SWAPNO collaborated with multiple digital financial service providers (bKash and Nagad) to provide G2P services within the national framework of the social safety nets delivery system among its beneficiaries through their mobile wallets. Moreover, the project partnered with two e-commerce platforms and connected with various urban market actors to sell their products. Through this, the beneficiaries got access to the urban market and received a fair price through digital financial transition using mobile wallets. From a risk management perspective, the project also introduced suitable and affordable microinsurance products, as to enhance the shock absorbing capacities and resistance among beneficiaries. During the reporting period, around 1,587 women beneficiaries are covered under microinsurance scheme and around 28 beneficiaries claimed and received payment from the insurance service provider. This increases beneficiaries interest to get quality health care services when its required.
Outcome 5 (Improved policies and mechanisms for sustaining benefits) focuses on improving policies and strengthening local government capacity to sustain SWAPNO IIs evidenced demonstration of impacts, specifically, to promote efficient and transparent implementation processes among local stakeholder partnerships. Under this outcome, the project is continuing its work on evidence-based advocacy and research to promote the scaleup of SWAPNO II model as a relevant tool for poverty graduation. No significant result has been reported so far, but the project is continuing its advocacy and research work expect to secure some remarkable result by the end of the project.
The project conducted a third-party evaluation during 2021 through Bangladesh Institute of Development Studies (BIDS) and some key findings are listed below:
- SWAPNO has successfully established partnerships with the Government, Private sector, and UN organizations that have contributed to the viability of the projects graduation model and ensured the well-being of the Ultra poor demographic dividend.
- SWAPNOs intervention enhanced livelihoods in poverty and disaster-prone districts of Bangladesh, using its innovative public asset model, empowered women, and reduced inequality towards sustainable and inclusive economic growth. Significant improvement in the savings and income level was observed in 3,564 beneficiary households, including 46% widowed, 26% abandoned, 19% divorced/separated, and 9% with a Person with Disability (PWD) family member.
- The rural women who received SWAPNOs various training are now better capacitated to be more vocal when approaching UP and local service providers. 3,564 women have taken life skills and livelihood skills training which helped them to enhance their capacity to engage in different income-generating activities.
- The digital financial system of the SWAPNO project went well because this system ensured access to financial institutions for 100% of its 3,564 most vulnerable, rural female-headed households.
- SWAPNO successfully mainstreamed gender equality and women empowerment by ensuring 100% access to financial institutions, improving their decision-making, self-confidence, agility, and asset/income management skills.
- More than 90% of SWAPNO beneficiaries are decision-makers, participate in social institutions, and are sole bread earners, and they have complete control over their assets and income.
- SWAPNO projects partnerships with formal sector institutions worked well to place women in formal sector jobs.
- SWAPNO has established a hotline for the beneficiary women for capturing grievance reports. It is an important tool for implementing the projects Internal Control Framework on fund disbursement and expenditures. This innovative approach has empowered SWAPNO women to raise their voices against extortion, delayed payment, and psychosocial or physical abuse, as they now instantly can share their problems and be provided solutions. This hotline has contributed to supporting both informal and formal sector beneficiaries.
- The development of climate-resilient homesteads particularly raising plinths of homesteads in low-lying char areas is one of the most significant interventions of SWAPNO as it has reduced the risk of disaster. The activity has been implemented in Gaibandha, Jamalpur, and Lalmonirhat districts as the plinth raise is an adaptation intervention or disaster risk reduction. A total of 198 households have been selected from Gaibandha, Jamalpur, and Lalmonirhat districts. Selected beneficiaries will receive cash grants to raise the plinth by December 2021.
The evaluation shows that the SWAPNO project has effectively improved the condition needed among beneficiaries to enable them to graduate out of poverty despite difficulties in organizing necessary funding and against the hardships that the global pandemic meant.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
